title: Unwanted Warrior Ryan Hoffman keen to play on in 2018
text:
Unwanted Warrior Ryan Hoffman keen to play on in 2018 MARVIN FRANCE Last updated 13:56, February 8 2017 ANDREW CORNAGA/PHOTOSPORT 
Unwanted at the Warriors next year, Ryan Hoffman is keeping his options open. 
Veteran back-rower Ryan Hoffman says he still has plenty to offer despite not being offered a new deal by the Warriors. 
Hoffman was dealt a double blow last week when it was announced that not only would he be replaced as captain by Roger Tuivasa-Sheck, but he would have to leave the club when his current contract expires at the end of the season. 
The former New South Wales and Australia representative turned 33 last month and having played more than 300 first grade games in the NRL and Super League, has subjected his body to plenty of wear and tear. 
But Hoffman made at clear at training on Wednesday that he has no plans on hanging up the boots. 
READ MORE: * Thurston blasts Nines turn-out 
"I was very disappointed," Hoffman said. "I enjoy playing for this club and I certainly enjoyed leading this club but decisions have been and they're only for the betterment of the club. 
"You certainly can't begrudge that, they've picked a great leader in Roger so nothing is going to change for me, on or off the paddock. 
"The big thing is I'm keen to play again next year and I'm really looking forward to pulling the boots on somewhere." 
As for where he plays next season, Hoffman said he has options and did not rule out a return to England, where he played for Wigan in 2011. Ad Feedback 
He will be replaced at the Warriors by his former Melbourne teammate and Kiwis international Tohu Harris, who has signed a four-year deal at Mt Smart from 2018. 
Hoffman has a long relationship with Warriors coach Stephen Kearney having played together at the Storm and admitted the decision took him by surprise. 
But he said Kearney, who broke the news to Hoffman two weeks ago, handled it in the best possible way. 
"Steve called me in his office, sat me down and told me straight up - that's all you can ask for. 
"Steve's a bloke I've known since I was 18 years old, played with and coached by. That's the only way to do these things, straight up and that's exactly what Steve did." 
Hoffman has been retained in the leadership group and insisted he would have no problems putting his personal disappointment aside to get behind Tuivasa-Sheck. 
At 23, the Warriors fullback, who makes his return from a serious injury in the trail match against the Storm on Saturday, is young for a skipper 
But Hoffman believes his youthful exuberance could be exactly what the club needs. 
"I suppose I told things the way they were at certain times last year," he added. 
"I'm sure Roger's going to be really positive about the way he goes about it. It could be a generational thing, they way he's always bouncing up and around. 
"We have a young group with a sprinkling of older guys so to have a young captain I think will put us in good stead." - Stuff
